quotes.text: If it is not right do not do it; if it is not true do not say it.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The greater the difficulty, the more glory in surmounting it. Skillful pilots gain their reputation from storms and tempests.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: He who spares the wicked injures the good.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Some things are in our control and others not. Things in our control are opinion, pursuit, desire, aversion, and, in a word, whatever are our own actions. Things not in our control are body, property, reputation, command, and, in one word, whatever are not our actions.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Make the best use of what is in your power, and take the rest as it happens.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: People are not disturbed by things, but by the views they take of them.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: We should love all our dear ones… but always with the thought that we have no promise that we may keep them forever—nay, no promise even that we may keep them for long.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: For mankind, evil is injustice and cruelty and indifference to a neighbour’s trouble, while virtue is brotherly love and goodness and justice and beneficence and concern for the welfare of your neighbour—with.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: A bad feeling is a commotion of the mind repugnant to reason, and against nature.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future, not to amuse ourselves with either hopes or fears but to rest satisfied with what we have, which is sufficient, for he that is so wants nothing. The greatest blessings of mankind are within us and within our reach. A wise man is content with his lot, whatever it may be, without wishing for what he has not.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Wealth is able to buy the pleasures of eating, drinking and other sensual pursuits-yet can never afford a cheerful spirit or freedom from sorrow.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: To accept injury without a spirit of savage resentment-to show ourselves merciful toward those who wrong us-being a source of good hope to them-is characteristic of a benevolent and civilized way of life.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: What good are gilded rooms or precious stones-fitted on the floor, inlaid in the walls, carried from great distances at the greatest expense? These things are pointless and unnecessary-without them isn’t it possible to live healthy? Aren’t they the source of constant trouble? Don’t they cost vast sums of money that, through public and private charity, may have benefited many?
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Events do not just happen, but arrive by appointment.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If we were to measure what is good by how much pleasure it brings, nothing would be better than self-control- if we were to measure what is to be avoided by its pain, nothing would be more painful than lack of self-control.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is not that we have so little time but that we lose so much. The life we receive is not short but we make it so; we are not ill provided but use what we have wastefully.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is a rough road that leads to the heights of greatness.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Or is it your reputation that’s bothering you? But look at how soon we’re all forgotten. The abyss of endless time that swallows it all. The emptiness of those applauding hands. The people who praise us; how capricious they are, how arbitrary. And the tiny region it takes place. The whole earth a point in space – and most of it uninhabited.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: To accuse others for one’s own misfortune is a sign of want of education. To accuse oneself shows that one’s education has begun. To accuse neither oneself nor others shows that one’s education is complete.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: To accept injury without a spirit of savage resentment-to show ourselves merciful toward those who wrong us-being a source of good hope to them-is characteristic of a benevolent and civilized way of life.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Often a very old man has no other proof of his long life than his age.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Seek not the good in external things;seek it in yourselves.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Happiness is a good flow of life.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you’re needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive – to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The key is to keep company only with people who uplift you, whose presence calls forth your best.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Whenever you are about to find fault with someone, ask yourself the following question: What fault of mine most nearly resembles the one I am about to criticize?
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: As is a tale, so is life: not how long it is, but how good it is, is what matters
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: In our control is the most beautiful and important thing, the thing because of which even the god himself is happy— namely, the proper use of our impressions. We must concern ourselves absolutely  with the things that are under our control and entrust the things not in our control to the universe.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Husband and wife should come together to craft a shared life, procreating children, seeing all things as shared between them-with nothing withheld or private to one another-not even their bodies.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Being good is the same as being a philosopher. If you obey your father, you will follow the will of a man; if you choose the philosopher’s life, the will of the universe. It is plain, therefore, that your duty lies in the pursuit of philosophy.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: They lose the day in expectation of the night, and the night in fear of the dawn.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: You will earn the respect of all if you begin by earning the respect of yourself. Don’t expect to encourage good deeds in people conscious of your own misdeeds.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: From good people you’ll learn good, but if you mingle with the bad you’ll destroy such soul as you had.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: No man is crushed by misfortune unless he has first been deceived by prosperity.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Choose to die well while you can; wait too long, and it might become impossible to do so.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: The soul becomes dyed with the color of its thoughts
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: People are frugal in guarding their personal property; but as soon as it comes to squandering time they are most wasteful of the one thing in which it is right to be stingy.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Man conquers the world by conquering himself.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: If you lay violent hands on me, you’ll have my body, but my mind will remain with Stilpo.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: Everything that happens is either endurable or not. If it’s endurable, then endure it. Stop complaining. If it’s unendurable… then stop complaining. Your destruction will mean its end as well. Just remember: you can endure anything your mind can make endurable, by treating it as in your interest to do so. In your interest, or in your nature.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: A gift consists not in what is done or given, but in the intention of the giver or doer.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The soul becomes dyed with the colour of its thoughts.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: A man must stand erect, not be kept erect by others.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: He who lives in harmony with himself lives in harmony with the universe
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: He who laughs at himself never runs out of things to laugh at.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: To win true freeedom you must be a slave to philosophy.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Nothing is more hostile to a firm grasp on knowledge than self-deception.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: If you accomplish something good with hard work, the labor passes quickly, but the good endures; if you do something shameful in pursuit of pleasure, the pleasure passes quickly, but the shame endures.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Observe always that everything is the result of change, and get used to thinking that there is nothing Nature loves so well as to change existing forms and make new ones like them.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The goal of life is living in agreement with Nature.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: He who is brave is free.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It’s not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it; and this you have the power to revoke at any moment.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: If you would be a reader, read; if a writer, write.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The universe is change; our life is what our thoughts make it.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Waste no more time arguing what a good man should be. Be one
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Be like the cliff against which the waves continually break; but it stands firm and tames the fury of the water around it.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master; he can anger you only when you permit yourself to be disturbed by him.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Better to trip with the feet than with the tongue.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: Very little is needed to make a happy life; it is all within yourself in your way of thinking.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Withdraw into yourself, as far as you can. Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom you yourself can improve. The process is mutual; for men learn while they teach.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: All cruelty springs from weakness.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Begin each day by telling yourself: Today I shall be meeting with interference, ingratitude, insolence, disloyalty, ill-will, and selfishness – all of them due to the offenders’ ignorance of what is good or evil.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: There is only one way to happiness and that is to cease worrying about things which are beyond the power or our will.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Either God wants to abolish evil, and cannot; or he can, but does not want to.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today. You are arranging what lies in Fortune’s control, and abandoning what lies in yours. What are you looking at? To what goal are you straining? The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Remember, it is not enough to be hit or insulted to be harmed, you must believe that you are being harmed. If someone succeeds in provoking you, realize that your mind is complicit in the provocation. Which is why it is essential that we not respond impulsively to impressions; take a moment before reacting, and you will find it easier to maintain control.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Demand not that things happen as you wish, but wish them to happen as they do, and you will go on well.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: God has entrusted me with myself. No man is free who is not master of himself. A man should so live that his happiness shall depend as little as possible on external things. The world turns aside to let any man pass who knows where he is going.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Every new beginning comes from some other beginning’s end.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Man is not worried by real problems so much as by his imagined anxieties about real problems.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbour says or does or thinks, but only at what he does himself, to make it just and holy.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them. Think constantly on the changes of the elements into each other, for such thoughts wash away the dust of earthly life.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: I have often wondered how it is that every man loves himself more than all the rest of men, but yet sets less value on his own opinion of himself than on the opinion of others.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: A person’s worth is measured by the worth of what he values.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Do not act as if you were going to live ten thousand years. Death hangs over you. While you live, while it is in your power, be good.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen more than we say.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It is unrealistc to expect people to see you as you see yourself.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If someone is able to show me that what I think or do is not right, I will happily change, for I seek the truth, by which no one was ever truly harmed. It is the person who continues in his self-deception and ignorance who is harmed.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: If any man despises me, that is his problem. My only concern is not doing or saying anything deserving of contempt.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Anger, if not restrained, is frequently more hurtful to us than the injury that provokes it.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: There are more things that frighten us than injure us, and we suffer more in imagination than in reality.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Remember that you ought to behave in life as you would at a banquet. As something is being passed around it comes to you; stretch out your hand, take a portion of it politely. It passes on; do not detain it. Or it has not come to you yet; do not project your desire to meet it, but wait until it comes in front of you. So act toward children, so toward a wife, so toward office, so toward wealth.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Since every man dies, it is better to die with distinction than to live long.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Well-being is realized by small steps, but is truly no small thing.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Enjoy present pleasures in such a way as not to injure future ones.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The key is to keep company only with people who uplift you, whose presence calls forth your best.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: No loss should be more regrettable to us than losing our time, for it’s irretrievable.
quotes.author: Zeno of Citium

quotes.text: Only the educated are free.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Fire tests gold, suffering tests brave men.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: If anyone tells you that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make excuses about what is said of you but answer, “He was ignorant of my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these alone.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it, if you have to, with the same weapons of reason which today arm you against the present.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: A ship should not ride on a single anchor, nor life on a single hope.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Perfection of character is this: to live each day as if it were your last, without frenzy, without apathy, without pretence.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Don’t explain your philosophy. Embody it.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: Death smiles at us all, but all a man can do is smile back
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The first rule is to keep an untroubled spirit. The second is to look things in the face and know them for what they are.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: We will train both soul and body when we accustom ourselves to cold, heat, thirst, hunger, scarcity of food, hardness of bed, abstaining from pleasures, and enduring pains.
quotes.author: Gaius Musonius Rufus

quotes.text: Men are disturbed not by things, but by the view which they take of them.
quotes.author: Epictetus

quotes.text: It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.
quotes.author: Seneca
